 There's something you learn quite early as a gay man - being squeamish about sex and its gooey details inhibits your ability to engage in safe sex (a category that includes abstinence). Only when you are willing and able to discuss sexual intercourse in a mature and clinical way, are you capable of engaging in dialogue about safe sex. 
 
 Unprotected oral sex, cunnilingus or fellatio, are both low risk activities. The risk derives from primarily from transmission from lesions on the genitals to lesions in the mouth. With a dental dam or condom, this risk becomes somewhat less than being struck by lightening. Proper use of a condom is necessary for this level of protection, and unfortunately there are still people who don't know how to use them properly. 
 
 Unprotected anal sex, like unprotected vaginal sex, is much more dangerous in terms of HIV transmission, as well as for a host of other STDs. But like protected oral sex, the risk of contracting HIV (and CID) through protected anal or vaginal sex is very low. This protection, again, depends on whether a condom is used properly. 
 
 Of course, these risks can be lowered even further (including risks of contracting other STDs) through screening for HIV and other STDs. Sexual monogamy also helps lower the risk.

So then am I to assume you agree that the easiest way to catch HIV is through anal intercourse?
 No, I'd say that the easiest way to catch HIV is sharing a needle with an HIV infected person. 
 
 The second easiest way, I'd say, is vaginal penetration. This is because some straight people, for whatever reason, think of HIV as something that only gays get. And, naturally, there are lots more straight people to engage in risky sexual behaviour like unprotected sex with strangers. Look at the whole of Africa, or Brazil for example, and you'll see that most people there are being infected through unprotected vaginal intercourse. 
 
 Unprotected anal intercourse with an HIV infected person is less or more risky depending on whether you're penetrating or being penetrated respectively. 
 
 Getting HIV from penetrating someone anally without protection is somewhat less risky than the chance of contracting HIV from being penetrated vaginally, as I understand these things.
 
 Protected anal sex is safer than unprotected vaginal sex, and roughly on par with unprotected oral sex. I say roughly because the risk of contracting HIV through oral sex depends very much on the state of each partner's oral and genital health - sores and open wounds significantly increase risk.
 
 Performing unprotected oral sex on someone with lesions on their genitals, for example, is much more dangerous than protected anal sex.
 
 I guess my point is that anal sex is more or less risky than other forms of sex depending on how and with who it's being performed. Very gentle anal penetration with a condom, good lube, and lots of foreplay is considerably less risky than rough unprotected vaginal penetration, for example. 
 
 Anal sex with an uninfected person, also, is far less risky than just about any kind of sex with an infected person. You can't contract HIV from someone who doesn't have it. 
 
 Another point is condom use - a 'female' condom, for example, is much safer for anal and vaginal use than regular condoms for a variety of reasons - resistant to most lube (doesn't corrode like latex), reduces friction on the receiver, and shifts control of protection to the more vulnerable party. 
 
 One of the problems with HIV in Africa is that many heterosexual men are unwilling to wear condoms, but equally unwilling to forego sex or allow their partners the right of refusal.

I don't believe there is much question but that Aids became a problem after the gay community first came down with several cases in the 1980s. As I recall it was a very promiscuous airline host that introduced it here in the U.S. or that is the concensus of the research I read.

 
 "Patient Zero" has been shown to be a myth...
 
 Much was made in the early years of the epidemic of a so-called 'Patient Zero' who was the basis of a complex "transmission scenario" compiled by Dr. William Darrow and colleagues at the Centre for Disease Control in the US. This epidemiological study showed how 'Patient O' (mistakenly identified in the press as 'Patient Zero') had given HIV to multiple partners, who then in turn transmitted it to others and rapidly spread the virus to locations all over the world. A journalist, Randy Shilts, subsequently wrote an article based on Darrow's findings, which named Patient Zero as a gay Canadian flight attendant called Gaetan Dugas. For several years, Dugas was vilified as a 'mass spreader' of HIV and the original source of the HIV epidemic among gay men. However, four years after the publication of Shilts' article, Dr. Darrow repudiated his study, admitting its methods were flawed and that Shilts' had misrepresented its conclusions.
 
 While Gaetan Dugas was a real person who did eventually die of AIDS, the Patient Zero story was not much more than myth and scaremongering.
